facts.fact_text: Residential property prices in Indonesia rose by 0.83% year-on-year in Q4 2025.

evidences.evidence_text: Residential property prices in Indonesia rose by 0.83% year-on-year in Q4 2025

facts.fact_text: The 0.83% increase in Q4 2025 was broadly stable from a 0.84% increase in Q3.

evidences.evidence_text: broadly stable from a 0.84% increase in Q3

facts.fact_text: The growth rate of 0.83% in Q4 2025 marks the slowest growth since the data series began in 2003.

evidences.evidence_text: marking the slowest growth since the data series began in 2003

facts.fact_text: Price growth slowed for medium-sized houses to 1.12% (vs 1.18% in Q3).

evidences.evidence_text: Price growth slowed for medium-sized houses (1.12% vs 1.18% in Q3)

facts.fact_text: Prices for large houses remained stable at 0.72%.

evidences.evidence_text: while prices for large houses remained stable (at 0.72%)

facts.fact_text: Small houses saw slightly faster growth at 0.76% (vs 0.71% in Q3).

evidences.evidence_text: and small houses saw slightly faster growth (0.76% vs 0.71% in Q3)

facts.fact_text: Among the 18 cities surveyed, 12 reported slower price growth.

evidences.evidence_text: Among the 18 cities included in the survey, 12 reported slower price growth

facts.fact_text: Palembang saw the sharpest slowdown in price growth, at 0.52% (vs. 1.06%).

evidences.evidence_text: with the sharpest slowdown seen in Palembang (0.52% vs. 1.06%)

facts.fact_text: Prices in Manado edged down by 0.04% after rising 0.03% in Q3.

evidences.evidence_text: while prices in Manado edged down by 0.04% after rising 0.03% in Q3.

evidence.evidence_text: The latest figures reflect a decline in purchasing power and a rise in layoffs, which contributed to the overall moderation in property prices.
The latest figures reflect a decline in purchasing power and a rise in layoffs, which contributed to the overall moderation in property prices.
